name: American Flamingo
description: It has deep pink feathers, a pink upper beak half, and red legs.
spread_note: Cuba, some other Caribbean islands, coastal parts of the South American mainland
food_note: Aquatic invertebrates including insects, small fish, microscopic algae
image_alt: American Flamingo, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
reproduction: Females lay a single egg, incubated alternately with the male for 27–31 days.
attractions: A close relative of the greater flamingo, sometimes considered the same species. It forms four distinct populations, with the Galápagos one critically endangered. Its lifestyle mirrors that of the Chilean flamingo.
breeding: The first American flamingos arrived at the zoo in 1960 from Paris. Wild birds came in 1965. One male from this group lived here until June 2013—48 years—and one female remains. The first successful breeding was in 1996. The chick, marked Prague 01, is a male and still part of our group.
